tasks: Centroidal state estimation for legged robots
methods: Projecting whole-body dynamics into nullspace of contact constraints
Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) for torque-based estimation
results: Improved recovery of centroidal states compared to direct computation
Demonstrated on a quadruped robot with different gaits
title: On the Use of Torque Measurement in Centroidal State Estimation
abstract: State of the art legged robots are either capable of measuring torque at the output of their drive systems, or have transparent drive systems which enable the computation of joint torques from motor currents. In either case, this sensor modality is seldom used in state estimation. In this paper, we propose to use joint torque measurements to estimate the centroidal states of legged robots. To do so, we project the whole-body dynamics of a legged robot into the nullspace of the contact constraints, allowing expression of the dynamics independent of the contact forces. Using the constrained dynamics and the centroidal momentum matrix, we are able to directly relate joint torques and centroidal states dynamics. Using the resulting model as the process model of an Extended Kalman Filter (EKF), we fuse the torque measurement in the centroidal state estimation problem. Through real-world experiments on a quadruped robot with different gaits, we demonstrate that the estimated centroidal states from our torque-based EKF drastically improve the recovery of these quantities compared to direct computation.
